string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Why do you need to reflect in this micro-credential?

search.slidetext: reflective writing support resource select the arrow to begin.

learning outcomes page 1 | 21 articulate the benefits of reflection for your active participation in this micro-credential. use reflection to improve your learning. write reflectively with an appropriate balance between personal and academic content. link theory and practice in reflective writing when required. after successfully completing the activities in this support resource, you will be able to: support resource: reflective writing select the arrows to navigate.

introduction page 2 | 21 what is reflection? reflection is a thinking process. when you reflect, you examine your thoughts in response to experiences, situations, events and information. you think back on prior experiences and examine your beliefs, values, attitudes and assumptions. reflection also involves making connections between existing knowledge and what you are learning. reflection in this micro-credential reflection is important as part of your learning and self-development. this support resource will help you build the essential skills required to write reflectively. in this micro-credential, you will be invited to engage supportively and constructively in an online network community, including sharing your reflections and supporting other learners. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

the characteristics of reflective writing page 3 | 21 judgement about right or wrong, good or bad. just a description or summary of an event simple problem solving just information, instructions or an argument reflective writing is not: an opportunity to gain knowledge and make meaning out of activities and experiences. a way of thinking to explore your learning personal thoughts and opinions in response to experiences, events or information reflective writing is: select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

incorrect you did not select the correct response. the correct answer was‘this is not reflective writing’. this example is only a recount of events, which means it is not reflective writing. to make this reflective, the writer would need to include their own response tothe events, as well as to reflect on their learning and consider future plans. continue continue continue continue continue continue that's right! you selected the correct response. this example is only a recount of events, which means it is not reflective writing. to make this reflective, the writer would need to include their own response tothe events, as well as to reflect on their learning and consider future plans. correct continue continue continue continue continue continue this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing submit submit submit submit submit submit page 4 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer activity: identifying reflective writing can you identify if the following example is reflective writing, or not? during the first meeting with my teaching colleagues, we discussed various strategies that could be used when working with students who consistently disrupt lessons. we chose two approaches to focus on so we can compare results when we next meet. support resource: reflective writing

incorrect you did not select the correct response. the correct answer was ‘this is reflective writing’. this is a good example of basic reflective writing, as it includes a summaryof events, what actions the writer took and the results of those actions, as well as their future plans for learning. continue continue continue continue continue continue that's right! you selected the correct response. this is a good example of basic reflective writing, as it includes a summaryof events, what actions the writer took and the results of those actions, as well as their future plans for learning. correct continue continue continue continue continue continue this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is not reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing this is reflective writing submit submit submit submit submit submit page 5 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer activity: identifying reflective writing can you identify if the following example is reflective writing, or not? during our next meeting, we spent time talking to better understand what we each have to offer and to ensure our approach to classroom management is better coordinated. this way of working meant i was able to learn more about my colleagues and the students i was working with, and i feel now better placed to plan classroom management strategies that will work for them. moving forward, i would like to develop my interpersonal skills and collaborate further with my colleagues as opportunities arise. support resource: reflective writing

reflective writing in this micro-credential page 6 | 21 comment on research and theory include references reflective writing is: based on your own experiences an expression of your own view written in the first person, unless discussing research and theory (third person) based on literature you have read a comparison of views reflective writing in this micro-credential can: be written in a formal style use subject specific language select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

research focused research focused your own experiences and perspectives your own experiences and perspectives written primarily in first person written primarily in first person based on other people’s views based on other people’s views determining if events/actions were good or bad determining if events/actions were good or bad supported by theory supported by theory page 7 | 21 select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect you did not select the correct response. select the ‘continue’ button to see the correct answer. continue continue continue continue continue continue activity: features of reflective writing submit submit submit submit submit submit your own experiences and perspectives your own experiences and perspectives your own experiences and perspectives your own experiences and perspectives your own experiences and perspectives written primarily in first person written primarily in first person written primarily in first person written primarily in first person written primarily in first person based on other people’s views based on other people’s views based on other people’s views based on other people’s views based on other people’s views supported by theory supported by theory supported by theory supported by theory supported by theory an argument an argument an argument an argument an argument simple problem solving simple problem solving simple problem solving simple problem solving simple problem solving are features of reflective writing not features of reflective writing can you identify which elements are features of reflective writing and which are not? sort the following elements by dragging them to the appropriate box. page 7 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer support resource: reflective writing

why do you need to reflect in this micro-credential? page 8 | 21 in this micro-credential, you are asked to reflect in the following contexts: sharing your knowledge and experiences, ideas and wonderings justifying the selection of strategies for teaching phonics appraising the impact of strategies for teaching phonics on your own practice constructively engaging with your peers throughout the course. although these contexts are all slightly different, the basic structure and language for your reflections will usually be the same. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

preparing to reflect 1: keep a journal structure your journal by asking yourself simple questions like these: what did i learn? what went well, and why? 2: reflect before, during and after an experience ongoing reflection will show how your knowledge and skills have developed. 3: seek feedback from colleagues and mentors to add depth to your reflection when you need to write reflectively, it is best if you can spend some time preparing for this task. here are some simple tips to help you get ready to write a reflective piece. what could i have done better? what are the long-term implications? page 9 | 21 select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

reflective writing language page 10 | 21 now that you are prepared to write a reflective piece, you need to think about what language is appropriate. reflective writing may be different to much of the writing that you do as it allows you to be subjective. subjective writing is all about your own opinions, experiences and point of view. objective writing is presented from a neutral position and is structured around different arguments supported by evidence from the literature. you may sometimes need to, or want to, use research and/or theory to support your reflections. however, not every point you make needs to be supported in this way. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

incorrect you did not select the correct response. the correct answer was ‘this is objective’. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective can you determine whether the following examples contain subjective or objective language? in one of my classes, there is a recurring issue with a student who consistently arrives late. this behaviour disrupts the class routine and negatively impacts the learning experience of other students. i've addressed the matter by reminding the student of the importance of punctuality, and its impact on their education and that of their peers. submit submit submit submit submit submit activity: subjective vs. objective language page 11 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer support resource: reflective writing

incorrect you did not select the correct response. the correct answer was ‘this is subjective’. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is objective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective this is subjective submit submit submit submit submit submit activity: subjective vs. objective language can you determine whether the following examples contain subjective or objective language? in one of my classes, i’m really concerned about a student who is repeatedly arriving late. i think this is because they spend too much time talking to their peers between classes. it's been causing disruptions, and it's clear that their learning is impacted, and so is the learning of the other students. i've taken the opportunity to have a one-on-one conversation with the student, emphasising the importance of being on time and how it can have a positive impact on their own educational experience. page 12 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer support resource: reflective writing

reflective writing language reflective writing is more than just being subjective instead of objective. here are some additional language conventions to keep in mind when you write your reflections. language should be formal while still subjective — limit casual language and colloquialisms. jargon and acronyms should not be assumed knowledge — they can be used where relevant but should be explained the first time they are mentioned. adjectives can be used to describe experiences. keep content of reflected relevant. avoid sharing any confidential or personal information. page 13 | 21 select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. correct that's right! you selected the correct response. this reflection should not include judgmental language (lazy), personal information (the student's name, jeff), or unexplained acronyms (pbis). continue continue continue continue continue continue activity: reflective writing language submit submit submit submit submit submit can you select the language in this reflection that is not appropriate for reflective writing? select three words in this reflection that do not align with the conventions of reflective writing. a lazy student in my english class has ongoing issues with punctuality. when jeff arrived late again yesterday, i responded quickly and reminded him about the importance of being on time. i am going to use a pbis strategy to attempt to resolve this issue. page 14 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer support resource: reflective writing

page 14 | 21 this reflection should not include judgmental language (lazy), personal information (the student's name, jeff) or unexplained acronyms (pbis). select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing incorrect you did not select the correct response. select the ‘continue’ button to see the correct answer. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. this reflection should not include judgmental language (lazy), personal information (the student's name, jeff), or unexplained acronyms (pbis). continue continue continue continue continue continue activity: reflective writing language submit submit submit submit submit submit can you select the language in this reflection that is not appropriate for reflective writing? select three words in this reflection that do not align with the conventions of reflective writing. a lazy student in my english class has ongoing issues with punctuality. when jeff arrived late again yesterday, i responded quickly and reminded him about the importance of being on time. i am going to use a pbis strategy to attempt to resolve this issue. page 14 | 21 select the ‘submit’ button to check your answer support resource: reflective writing

reflective writing structure page 15 | 21 star-l/p star-l/p star-l/p 4rs 4rs 4rs select each to learn more. now that you know how to prepare for your reflections and have an understanding of the language required, let’s take a look at the final consideration — how to structure your reflections. there are a number of different reflective writing structures. this support resource recommends two different approaches you can use to guide the structure of your reflections: the star-l/p structure for basic reflective writing the 4rs for in-depth reflections involving theory or research. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

reasoning: what important factors underlying incidents / issues can you identify? how are these factors important when understanding events? how is your reasoning supported by theory / literature? what other perspectives should be considered? are ethics involved? how might a more experienced person handle this? reconstructing: project yourself into the future; how would you deal with some of the issues / incidents you observed? is there more than one option? are your ideas supported by theory? how do you think your actions would be received? relating: connect your experiences with your own skills, experience, knowledge, personal goals and development. have you ever observed something similar or had similar experiences? were the conditions similar or different? what knowledge and skills were required to deal with these experiences? did you identify areas for personal development? reporting & responding: report on your experiences. make observations and express your opinion, raising relevant questions. 4rs reflective writing structure reporting & responding relating reasoning reconstructing the 4rs structure is recommended for more in-depth reflections. it is best used when you need to analyse your experiences and incorporate theory to deepen your reflections, such as when writing reflective reports. this structure is also appropriate for writing about your professional development as an educator, which is an essential part and requirement of the profession. select each element to the left to find out more. page 18 | 21 select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

learning / planning: what did you learn from these experiences? what skills, abilities or deeper understanding have you developed? how might you apply what you have learnt to other situations? what plans can you make for the future based on these experiences? action: what did you do? based on existing knowledge, why did you take these actions? result / reflect: how did your actions affect the outcome related to the task? how does the result align with your personal goals or development? what needs further investigation or thought? task: what did you have to do? how did you interact with others? situation: describe the environment and the people, i.e. the background information and context of the events which occurred. star-l/p reflective writing structure page 16 | 21 situation task action result / reflect learning / planning the star-l/p structure is recommended as a starting point for your reflections. it is focused on your experiences, how you responded to them and how you plan to act in similar future situations. the star-l/p structure is also useful to remember when applying for work, as employers often look for reflections following this format in interviews and applications. by using this format to structure a response to an employer, you can demonstrate your capacity for reflection and growth in the workplace. select each element on the left to find out more. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

page 17 | 21 situation situation task task action action result / reflect result / reflect learning / planning learning / planning during my placement, i had the opportunity to present my research findings to a group of my co-workers. during my placement, i had the opportunity to present my research findings to a group of my co-workers. during my placement, i had the opportunity to present my what’s next? page 20 | 21 reflection as part of reflective practice reflective writing is an essential skill to continue to develop as it will provide you with a structure for reflecting as part of your ongoing professional learning. being able to continuously reflect on your actions and develop your skills in response to this is demonstrating reflective practice and is a defining characteristic of professional growth. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing

you have completed this activity, and can now return to the course. well done! summary page 21 | 21 ask yourself the following questions next time you undertake a piece of reflective writing. where am i recording my reflective writing? have i balanced personal content with relevant research and/or theory? have i followed an appropriate reflective writing structure? is my reflection subjective? have i adhered to confidentiality requirements? is the language in my reflective writing appropriate? now that you have completed this support resource, you hopefully feel more confident to write reflectively. select the arrows to navigate. support resource: reflective writing
